Graphical abstract Recently perovskite materials have received extensive attention for dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction due to their stable ordered crystalline structure. In this work, materials with ionic substitutions of Ru, Pt, and Pd in LaAlO3 perovskite were synthesized using solution combustion synthesis route. The characterizations of catalysts were carried out by XRD, TEM, XPS, STEM, and BET surface area analyser. H2-TPR was performed to examine the strong metal support interaction between active metal and support that improve the resistance of the perovskite structure. The catalytic activity of these catalysts was examined for DRM. Stable conversion of both CH4 and CO2 were observed on stability test experiments for 50 h over Ru substituted LaAlO3 catalyst. This indicates that it is a highly stable and coke resistant catalyst for DRM. TEM and STEM results show the deactivation of Pt and Pd incorporated LaAlO3 due to sintering and carbon deposition. The apparent activation energy was determined from Arrhenius plot which was found to be 86 kJ mol−1 and 72 kJ mol−1 over LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ for CH4 and CO2 consumption, respectively. DRM reaction mechanism was proposed via formation of oxycarbonates over LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ . Keywords Syngas LaAlO3perovskite Solution combustion synthesis Dry reforming of methane 1 Introduction Syngas (CO + H2), is a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide, a key intermediate for the production of hydrogen, ammonia and value-added chemicals such as Fischer-Tropsch derived liquid fuels, and methanol [1–3]. Production of syngas via reforming of hydrocarbons has gained much attention in the past decade. The most common employed hydrocarbon source is methane. Syngas can be produced via various technologies such as steam reforming (SRM), dry reforming (DRM), partial oxidation (POM) and auto thermal reforming (ARM) from methane. Predominately they differ in production of CO/H2 ratio, oxidant used, and energies of respective technology. Syngas production via DRM, which utilizes the most important greenhouse gases CH4 and CO2, has received growing scientific interest in the recent past. The dry reforming of methane is represented as (1) C H 4 + C O 2 ↔ 2 C O + 2 H 2 Δ H 298 K o = 247 k J m o l − 1 DRM is a highly endothermic reaction that has to be conducted at high temperature and it yields H2/CO ratio close to unity, which is favourable for the industrial production of oxygenates, methanol and long chain hydrocarbons [4,5]. Although DRM is environmental friendly, it has not been commercialized due to deactivation of catalyst by coke deposition and sintering of active metal at high temperature during the reaction. Thermodynamics of DRM indicates that the coke formation is usually associated with high temperature, feed ratio of CH4/CO2, and the nature of catalyst [6,7]. The most prominent carbon formation pathways are methane decomposition and carbon monoxide disproportionation. Encapsulated carbon is found to be responsible for catalyst deactivation while amorphous carbon is released in the form of CO [8]. Thus, catalysts are highly sensitive for methane reforming reactions due to coke formation. The activation of both CH4 and CO2 in DRM possess relatively higher activation energies compared to individual CH4 and CO2 activation. Therefore, development of catalyst with high activity, selectivity, and resistance to carbon formation for DRM is essential. DRM has been studied extensively over Ni based catalysts and serious stability problem of those catalysts due to coke deposition was reported [9,10]. Both stability and catalytic activity of catalysts are equally important for high temperature reforming reactions. Noble metals with various supports are highly active and stable catalysts for dry reforming of methane due to high resistance to coke formation. The observed activity order of noble metal is as follows Rh > Ru > Ir > P t > Pd [11–16]. The relatively inexpensive and most active noble metal Ru based catalysts were explored for DRM [17–19]. It is usually accepted that the activation of both CH4 on active metal and CO2 on support takes place. Literature emphasizes that the support is also as important as the active metal for dry reforming of methane. The promising support should be thermally stable and promote more active sites. Moreover, the support also plays a crucial role in catalytic reactions by offering certain key properties such as acid-base characteristics, high oxygen storage capacity, reducibility and strong metal–support interaction for high activity by minimizing the carbon deposition. Ioannis et al. [15] studied the effect of support on the activity, selectivity, and resistance to carbon deposition over Rh supported catalysts. They observed that ceria–zirconia support minimized carbon formation by maintaining Rh in metallic state compared to alumina and alumina-ceria-zirconia. Several supports and combined such as SiO2, Al2O3, CeO2, La2O3 have been investigated extensively for DRM [20–24]. CO2 activation depends on acid-base characteristics of support that could be activated by forming formates and oxy-carbonates on acidic support (Al2O3) and basic support (La2O3) respectively [25]. Li et al. [26] have studied the DRM over Ru supported Mg-Al oxides. The higher catalytic activity of Ru/MgO and Ru/Mg3 (Al)O was speculated due to the strong basicity of the support with more available Ru° surface atoms. In addition to conventional supports, crystalline mixed oxides such as perovskite, pyrochlores, fluorite, are employed for DRM due to their thermal stability at high temperatures [15,27,28]. The effect of noble metal substitution at B-site of LaZr2O7 has been studied for DRM by Pakhare et al. [29] and they reported that higher resistance to coke deposition was observed for 1%Ru substituted LaZr2O7 compared to 0.5 %Ru/Al2O3. Moreover, the activation of CO2 takes place at the La site by forming La2O2CO3 that further react with carbon formed from methane to produce CO. Mixed oxides such as perovskite (ABO3) type material have been studied as promising support for DRM due to their structure and ability to facilitate high metal dispersion [30–32]. Among the perovskite ceramic material, LaAlO3 becomes attractive for reforming reactions [33–35]. However, there are only few studies on noble metal incorporated LaAlO3 for DRM. LaAlO3 was synthesized using various methods such as sol–gel, hydrothermal, and solution combustion synthesis [36,37]. In the present study, LaAlO3 and noble metal substituted LaAlO3 have been synthesized using solution combustion synthesis, which is a highly versatile and efficient technique to synthesize a variety of materials. Characterizations such as XRD, XPS, TEM and STEM have performed thoroughly for synthesized catalysts. DRM reactions were carried out over these catalysts and reaction mechanism was proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts LaAlO3 and LaAl1-xMxO3-δ (M = Ru, Pt, Pd, x = 0.02) were synthesized using a single step solution combustion synthesis route. Lanthanum nitrate (La (NO3)3. 6H2O, SDFCL, India), aluminium nitrate (Al (NO3)3. 9H2O, SDFCL, India), ruthenium chloride (RuCl3, sigma aldrich, India), chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6, sigma aldrich, India), palladium chloride (PdCl2, sigma aldrich, India) and glycine (C2H5NO2, merck, India) as a fuel, were used as precursors for preparation of solid solution LaAl1-xMxO3-δ. In the preparation of LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3-δ, stoichiometric amounts of precursors were mixed in 30 mL DI water and sonicated for 5 min to ensure a clear solution. The obtained solution was heated in a preheated muffle furnace at 400 °C ± 10 °C. The combustion started with dehydration and voluminous combustion was observed that yielded a porous solid product liberating the combustion gases. The obtained solid product was well grounded and calcined at 700 °C for 3 h for dry reforming of methane reactions. The similar synthesis protocol was followed for LaAl0.98Pt0.02O3-δ and LaAl0.98Pd0.02O3-δ, respectively. 2.2 Characterizations of catalysts The synthesized catalysts were characterized using the techniques such as XRD, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and TEM. X-ray diffraction pattern of the synthesized catalysts was obtained on Rigaku-X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu-Kα radiation source (λ =1.5406 Å) and monochromatic source. The scan rate 0.6°/min with steps of 0.02° in the 2θ range of 10°-90° was maintained. XPS spectra of prepared catalysts were recorded on AXIS Ultra with AlKα as a radiation source. TEM images, high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern and scanning electron transmission microscopy (STEM) were collected on FEI-Titan Themis 300 kV. Specific surface area and nitrogen adsorption isotherms were obtained by BET analyser (Micro meritics ASAP 2020) at 77 K. Prior to each experiment, the sample was degassed at 200 °C for 7 h. Temperature programming reduction with H2 experiments were conducted in quartz reactor tube over 10 mg synthesized catalyst, loaded at the centre of the quartz tube with ceramic wool, in the range of temperature 50 °C–750 °C. 30 mL/min of 5 % H2 – Ar gas mixture (Chemix gases, India) was used to determine the H2 consumption during the reduction using equipped thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The PID controller (Culture Instruments, India) was used to control the catalyst bed temperature with a constant rate of 10 °C/min. The amount of carbon formation was found using thermogravimetric analysis. It was performed over 5 mg of spent catalyst under pure oxygen conditions with a rate of 10 °C/min in the range of 30 °C–800 °C. FTIR spectra of catalysts were recorded on Perkin Elmer Frontier with 12 scans and 4 cm−1 resolution in the range of 500–4000 cm−1. 2.3 Dry reforming of methane experiments Catalytic dry reforming of methane was conducted in packed bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. 100 mg of catalyst in the form of pellet with 60/80 mesh size was loaded between ceramic wool plugs at centre of the reactor. The catalyst was diluted with inert silica gel beads and 1 cm catalyst bed was maintained. The reactor connected with a K-type thermocouple at the centre of the catalyst bed was inserted into a tubular furnace. A PID controller (Culture Instruments, India) was used to maintain isothermal conditions during reaction. Catalyst reduction was conducted with the flow rate of 20 mL/min of pure hydrogen at 400 °C for 1 h and the temperature was increased at the rate of 2 °C/min until 400 °C. 50 mL/min of nitrogen gas was passed over the catalyst for 30 min after the reduction process to remove any adsorbed hydrogen and the bed temperature was decreased to room temperature. Feed gas mixture consisting 10 % CH4, 10 % CO2 and 80 % N2 was passed over the bed at a flow rate of 100 mL/min. All the experiments were carried out at constant gas hourly space velocity GHSV, of 48,000 h−1. Product gas mixture was analysed using a gas chromatography equipped with both thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and flame ionization detector (FID) with methanizer. The mixture of CO and CO2 was separated using a 3 m long Haysep-A column. The flame ionization detector with methanizer (FID-methanizer) was used to detect CO and CO2. The methanizer operates at 350 °C with Ru catalyst. The separation of H2 and N2 were done using a 2 m long molecular sieve 5A column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of catalysts Fig. 1 (a) shows the X-ray diffraction pattern of Ru, Pt, and Pd substituted perovskite LaAlO3 including pristine material. The characteristic diffraction peaks of the synthesized perovskite catalysts were found to be in agreement with reference XRD pattern of LaAlO3 (PCPDF-09-0072) which is a rhombohedral crystal system with R-3 m space group. No other diffraction lines correspond to Ru, Pt, and Pd or their oxides were identified. The single phase of highly crystalline perovskite LaAlO3 was confirmed for all synthesized catalysts. A very small leftward shift in diffraction line position was observed for noble metal substituted perovskite LaAlO3 compared to pristine material LaAlO3 that testifies the formation of solid solution (LaAl1-xMxO3- δ ) for incorporation of Ru, Pt, and Pd in LaAlO3. The obtained XRD pattern of the synthesized perovskite catalysts were refined by Jana 2006. The refined profile of the perovskite LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ , catalyst was shown in Fig. 1(b). In this refinement of XRD pattern, Pseudo-Voigt function for peak shape and Legendre polynomial with 16 terms for background function was used. The results of the refinement analysis are tabulated in Table 1 . The observed shift in lattice parameters of Ru, Pt, and Pd substituted LaAlO3 compared to pristine LaAlO3 indicates the possible metal substitution in LaAlO3 lattice. The most intense reflection plane (104) was used to determine the crystallize size of the synthesized perovskite catalysts using Scherrer’s formula, d = (0.9 λ/ β Cosθ), where d is in nm, λ is the wavelength of the Cukα X-ray in Å (1.5406 Å), β is the full width half maximum (FWHM) of the diffraction peak in radiance. The obtained results are reported in Table 1. The observed N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of type II for synthesized catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 [38]. Specific surface area, total pore volume and mean pore diameter of the synthesized catalysts are presented in Table 2 . The surface area of synthesized catalysts was decreased upon substitution of noble metal in LaAlO3 perovskite lattice and low surface area was observed which might be due the high calcination temperature. The pore volume was also decreased upon substitution of Ru, Pt and Pd as shown in Table 2 compared to pristine LaAlO3 Fig. 3 shows the respective TEM micrographs, HRTEM and diffraction images of as synthesized catalysts. The non-homogeneous particle size formation with uneven shape and agglomeration were observed in respective bright field images. The calculated average particle size was found in the range of 28–43 nm and the particle size increased upon of substitution of Ru, Pt and Pd. The results are comparable with calculated crystallite sizes from XRD and tabulated in Table 2. No diffraction lines belong to substituted active metal and the variation in d-spacing value of metal substituted LaAlO3 compared pristine LaAlO3 confirms the ionic substitution of Ru, Pt, and Pd in LaAlO3 lattice. The TEM analysis was performed for spent catalysts after stability study at 650 °C for 50 h and the TEM micrographs and HRTEM of spent catalysts were displayed in Fig. 4 . The average particle size was not increased in case of Ru substituted LaAlO3 which was found to be 47 nm. However, the particle size increment was observed for Pt and Pd substituted LaAlO3 from 38 nm, 40 nm–63 nm and 62 nm respectively. The amorphous carbon formation was observed, which was shown in Fig. 4 with an arrow. Ionic substitution of Ru, Pt, and Pd in pristine LaAlO3 was confirmed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The wide spectra and core level spectra of Ru3d for LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ was presented in Fig. 5 . All the binding energies were calibrated using the C1S binding energy 284.6 eV. The identified peaks in Ru3d spectra (after deconvolution) are at binding energies around 282.4 eV and 286.5 eV. Both are attributed to 3+ oxidation state of Ru [39]. The results clearly indicate the ionic active metal substitution in LaAlO3 lattice. Fig. 6 shows the wide spectrum and the deconvoluted Ru3d spectra for LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ after stability study at 650 °C for 50 h. The XPS spectra shows that no significant shift in binding energy occurred after chemical reaction and it can be affirmed by the H2-TPR results. Fig. 7 shows the scanning transmission electron microscopy images of Ru, Pt, and Pd substituted LaAlO3 before reaction and after reaction. The homogenous dispersion was observed before reaction for Ru, Pt and Pd. However, agglomeration was observed after reaction in the case of Pd and Pt. These results are consistent with TEM and XPS. H2-TPR reduction profiles of the synthesized catalysts are displayed in Fig. 8 and it was observed very low intensity peaks to investigate the metal support interaction. In case of pristine LaAlO3 perovskite, a very small intensity reduction peak was observed around 625 °C that can be ascribed to the reduction of bulk oxide phase. However, when Ru, Pt, and Pd partially substituted in LaAlO3, the reduction peaks were observed at different temperatures compared to pristine support indicating the synergetic effect which improve the resistance of the perovskite structure. Moreover, the low intensity reduction peak was shifted to lower temperature around 570 °C compared to pristine LaAlO3 that reveals the effect of active metal substitution in LaAlO3. The reduction peak at lower temperature around 130 °C for all catalysts represents the metal reduction [40]. All the synthesized perovskite catalysts were calcined at 700 °C which is close to maximum methane conversion temperature and the above characterizations clearly show there is no significant effect of calcination temperature during the running of DRM reaction. 3.2 FTIR study Fig. 9 (a) and (b) shows the FTIR profile of all the catalysts before reaction and after reaction. The peaks were observed in the carbonate region for both before reaction and after reaction. The observed strong and sharp peak at 650 cm−1 in both cases for all the catalysts was assigned to the AlO6 octahedral (perovskite structure) in LaAlO3. Thus, it confirms the formation of the perovskite material. The identified peaks around 1400 cm−1 and 1495 cm−1 are assigned to asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of COO- carbonate species [41,42]. The intensity of these peaks was increased for Ru, Pd and Pt substituted LaAlO3 compared to the pristine support. On the other hand, one new peak was observed to be Al (OH) vibrations around 1085 cm−1 in case of spent catalysts along with other peaks around 1500 cm−1 and 1390 cm−1. 3.3 Activity studies The catalytic activity of the synthesized perovskite catalysts was tested for DRM as discussed in the section 2.3 in a differential reactor. The conversion of CH4 and CO2 for Ru, Pt and Pd substituted LaAlO3 and pristine LaAlO3 as a function of temperature were shown in Fig. 10 . In case of pristine LaAlO3, the conversion of CH4 was not observed but around 15 % of CO2 conversion was observed at 800 °C. The results showed that all the 2% noble metal (Ru, Pt and Pd) partially substituted perovskite LaAlO3 catalysts are active for DRM and the activity was started from 400 °C. LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ showed highest conversion of both CH4 and CO2 at each temperature compared to LaAl0.98Pt0.02O3- δ and LaAl0.98Pd0.02O3- δ. At 800 °C, 100 % of CO2 conversion was observed for Ru and Pt substituted LaAlO3 and only 80 % of CO2 conversion occurred for Pd substituted LaAlO3. 86 %, 60 % and 65 % conversion of CH4 was identified at 800 °C for LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ , LaAl0.98Pt0.02O3- δ and LaAl0.98Pd0.02O3- δ respectively. The calculated H2/CO ratio at different temperatures for all three synthesized catalysts was shown in Fig. 11 . The increased H2/CO ratio was observed with temperature from 400 °C to 600 °C. The observed constant H2/CO ratio is 0.85, 0.6 and 0.8 after 600 °C for Ru, Pt and Pd substituted LaAlO3 respectively. Reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction takes place along with DRM simultaneously which produces more CO by consuming H2. (2) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ C O + H 2 O Δ H 298 K o = 41.2 k J m o l − 1 Further, the DRM experiments were performed over various amounts of catalyst to determine the activation energy with respective CH4 and CO2 at same reaction conditions in differential reactor for all three catalysts. Fig. 12 (a) shows the effect of W/FCH4 and W/FCO2 on conversion of CH4 and CO2 respectively for LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ. The rates of reaction with respective CH4 and CO2 at different temperatures were determined using the slope of the kinetic regime of Fig. 12(b). The apparent activation energies with respect to CH4 and CO2 were calculated from Arrhenius plot which were found to be 86 kJ mol−1 and 72 kJ mol−1 respectively. The obtained higher apparent activation energy based on CH4 consumption compared CO2 consumption supports that methane dissociation is the rate determining step. 3.4 Stability study The catalytic stability of all three catalysts was investigated by performing the time on stream experiments over the reduced catalysts with same reaction condition at 650 °C for 50 h and it was displayed in Fig. 13 . Methane decomposition and carbon monoxide disproportionation are the main sources for carbon formation. (3) C H 4 ↔ C ( S ) + 2 H 2 Δ H 298 K o = 75 k J m o l − 1 (4) 2 C O ↔ C ( S ) + C O 2 Δ H 298 o = − 171 k J m o l − 1 No significant decrease in conversion was identified in the case of LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ which can confirm the high stability. However, carbon formation was confirmed by TEM analysis and the formed carbon might be filamentous type which can oxidize to form CO. The decreased conversion was observed for Pt and Pd substituted LaAlO3 at the end of 35 h and 25 h, respectively. The metal sintering and carbon formation both might be the cause for decreased activity, as observed in TEM results of spent catalysts. The coke formation on spent catalysts after DRM was found to be 15 mg, 45 mg and 105 mg g of catalyst for Ru, Pt and Pd substituted LaAlO3 catalysts respectively. It is well reported that the platinum group elements are responsible for CH4 activation and CO2 can be activated over support. Several types of reaction pathways were addressed including power law model, Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism, Eley-Ridel (E-R) mechanism and micro kinetic analysis based models in the literature [43–45]. Several studies postulated the DRM reaction mechanism over Ru based catalysts. Srikanth et al. have proposed the DRM reaction mechanism over Ni based perovskite catalysts with the help of in situ FTIR study and the hydroxyl and formate species were observed as intermediate species during the reaction. They have speculated that the produced hydrogen from CH4 dissociation can form hydroxyl species on support and the adsorbed CO2 reacts with H/OH species to produce formate species, which further decompose to release CO [46]. Satyapaul et al. [47] have performed the in situ DRIFTS experiments to identify the intermediate specie during the DRM reaction over Ru/TiO2 surface. The obtained results show that the dry reforming of methane followed the Eley-Ridel mechanism without adsorption of CO on support. Ferreira et al. [48] proposed the bi functional mechanism for DRM over Ru/Al2O3 with the help of infrared spectroscopy and isotopic tracing experiments. The basicity of the catalyst surface enhances the activation of CO2. The kinetics of DRM has been investigated over basic nature of La2O3 supported catalysts which helps in the activation of CO2 through formation of oxycarbonates [49]. Bobin et al. [50] have hypothesized that the DRM reaction mechanism over Ru, Pt and Ni doped ceria-zirconia catalysts using in situ FTIR and SSITKA. They have observed the formation of more abundant bridged carbonate bands upon contacting the CO2 with La containing samples compared to other catalysts. They also confirmed the intermediate species as carbonates only by using transient pulse experiments. In this present study, we have considered the reaction mechanism as reported in literature over Ni/La2O3 and Rh/La2O3-SiO2 [51,52] and the kinetic parameters were determined by fitting the kinetic model with experimental data. Based on above results and literature, we have proposed the DRM reaction mechanism via formation of oxycarbonates over LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ. The following elementary steps were considered as follows (5) C H 4 + M ⟷ K 1 M _ C H 4 (6) M _ C H 4 ⟶ k 2 M _ C + 2 H 2 (7) C O 2 + S ⟷ K 3 S _ C a r b o n a t e (8) S _ C a r b o n a t e + M _ C ⟶ k 4 2 C O + M + S Eq. (5) indicates the reversible adsorption of methane on active metal (M = Ru). The dissociation of methane and H2 formation is represented by eq. (6) which is the rate determining step. Eq. (7) refers the formation of oxycarbonates due to strong contact between CO2 and support. The reaction between oxycarbonates and carbon deposition of methane dissociation to form CO is represented by Eq. (8) The coverage of CH4 on active metal and carbonate on support can be written as (9) θ M _ C H 4 = K 1 p C H 4 θ M (10) θ S _ c a r b o n a t e = K 3 p C O 2 1 + K 3 p C O 2 The site balance for active metal and support can be represented as (11) θ M + θ M _ C H 4 + θ M _ C = 1 (12) θ S + θ S _ c a r b o n a t e = 1 (13) θ M = K 3 k 4 p C O 2 k 2 K 1 p C H 4 1 + K 3 p C O 2 + K 3 k 4 p C O 2 1 + K 1 p C H 4 (14) θ M _ C = K 1 k 2 p C H 4 1 + K 3 p C O 2 k 2 K 1 p C H 4 1 + K 3 p C O 2 + K 3 k 4 p C O 2 1 + K 1 p C H 4 The final rate expression for the methane consumption as follows (15) r C H 4 = K 1 k 2 K 3 k 4 p C H 4 p C O 2 k 2 K 1 p C H 4 1 + K 3 p C O 2 + K 3 k 4 p C O 2 1 + K 1 p C H 4 (16) 1 r C H 4 = 1 K 3 k 4 1 p C O 2 + 1 K 1 k 2 1 p C H 4 + 1 k 2 + 1 k 4 Where θ M , θ M _ C H 4 and θ M _ C refers to the fractional vacant sites, fractional coverage of methane and fractional coverage of carbon on Ru sites, respectively. θ S and θ S _ c a r b o n a t e represents the unoccupied and occupied with carbonates surface sites respectively. The kinetic parameters were evaluated from the linear fit of 1 r C H 4 with 1 p C H 4 and 1 p C O 2 as shown in Fig.14 . Eq. (16) has been derived by methane dissociation (Eq. (6) with rate constant k2) as the rate determining step. Therefore, k2 is very small. In Eq. (16) 1 r C H 4 is plotted against 1 p C H 4 keeping p C O 2 constant as shown in Fig. 14(a). The slopes and intercepts give 1/K1k2 and 1/K3k4+1/k2+1/k4 respectively. Similarly, plot of 1 r C H 4 vs 1 p C O 2 is linear as shown in Fig. 14(b).The slopes and intercepts are 1/K3k4 and 1/K1k2+1/k2+1/k4 respectively. Therefore, 1/k2 is much greater than 1/k4. Thus, 1/k4 can be neglected from eq. (16). The obtained kinetic parameters K1, k2 and K3K4 were tabulated in Table 3 . The product K3k4 is obtained ∼ 1 at the operating temperatures. The parity plot showed a good fit (Fig. 15 ) between experimental and predicted rate of reaction at different temperatures which indicates the estimated kinetic parameters are correct [52,53]. The conversions of both CH4 and CO2 are below equilibrium values for all catalysts and the RWGS reaction is likely to be the responsible for observed lower H2/CO ratio. Incorporation of Ru at B-site in ABO3 perovskite catalysts enhanced the catalytic activity and resistance to coke formation for reforming reactions [54]. Low specific surface area has been reported for perovskite material which depends on its calcination temperature. The decreased surface area was observed upon substitution of Ru, Pt and Pd in LaAlO3 and the lattice expansion due to higher ionic radius of active metal might be the cause for it [55]. Thermally stable and low surface area perovskite materials are more suitable for dry reforming reaction which may suppress the sintering and side reactions [56]. Rostrup-Nielson et al. have found higher activity with low carbon formation for Ru and Rh compared to Pt, Pd, Ni and Ir [57]. LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ catalyst showed highest activity with low carbon formation compared to Pt and Pd modified LaAlO3. Thus, the observed stable conversion of CH4 and CO2 in time on stream experiments for 50 h over Ru substituted LaAlO3 catalyst is indicating the highly stable and coke resistant catalyst for DRM. Moreover, TEM and STEM results clearly showed the sintering stability of LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ catalyst. In addition, H2-TPR results suggest that Ru metal was not reduced significantly due to its strong interaction with LaAlO3 perovskite that is consistent with XPS results. However, the observed low carbon formation over Ru catalyst that might involve in the carbon gasification as proposed reaction pathway. Haibin et al. [58] studied the influence of Ru on coke formation and gasification and it was observed that the Ru enhanced carbon gasification rate with increasing the activation barrier for CH4 dissociation. The observed coke formation and sintering might be the reason for the observed deactivation of Pt and Pd substituted LaAlO3. TEM and STEM results clearly demonstrate the deactivation of Pt and Pd substituted LaAlO3 due to sintering and carbon formation. 4 Conclusions The synthesised single phase LaAlO3 and Ru, Pt and Pd substituted LaAlO3 perovskite materials by solution combustion synthesis route were confirmed by XRD. The higher catalytic activity was observed for LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ compared to LaAl0.98Pt0.02O3- δ and LaAl0.98Pd0.02O3- δ. The Ru substitution in LaALO3 offers the thermal stability due to strong interaction between Ru and Al which was confirmed by H2-TPR and XPS results. However, carbon formation was observed, which can be converted to CO by gasification over active metal. The observed stable conversion of CH4 and CO2 in stability test experiments for 50 h over Ru substituted LaAlO3 catalyst indicates the highly stable and selective catalyst for DRM. The observed coke formation and sintering might be the reason for the deactivation of Pt and Pd substituted LaAlO3. TEM and STEM results are clearly demonstrating the deactivation of Pt and Pd substituted LaAlO3 due to sintering and carbon formation. The apparent activation energies were found to be 86 kJ mol−1 and 72 kJ mol-1 with CH4 and CO2 consumption respectively over LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ . coredata.dc:description: Recently perovskite materials have received extensive attention for dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction due to their stable ordered crystalline structure. In this work, materials with ionic substitutions of Ru, Pt, and Pd in LaAlO3 perovskite were synthesized using solution combustion synthesis route. The characterizations of catalysts were carried out by XRD, TEM, XPS, STEM, and BET surface area analyser. H2-TPR was performed to examine the strong metal support interaction between active metal and support that improve the resistance of the perovskite structure. The catalytic activity of these catalysts was examined for DRM. Stable conversion of both CH4 and CO2 were observed on stability test experiments for 50 h over Ru substituted LaAlO3 catalyst. This indicates that it is a highly stable and coke resistant catalyst for DRM. TEM and STEM results show the deactivation of Pt and Pd incorporated LaAlO3 due to sintering and carbon deposition. The apparent activation energy was determined from Arrhenius plot which was found to be 86 kJ mol−1 and 72 kJ mol−1 over LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ for CH4 and CO2 consumption, respectively. DRM reaction mechanism was proposed via formation of oxycarbonates over LaAl0.98Ru0.02O3- δ .
coredata.dc:title: Syngas production via CO2 reforming of methane over noble metal (Ru, Pt, and Pd) doped LaAlO3 perovskite catalyst
